text: Your Thursday Evening BriefingHere’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
Listen to ‘Rabbit Hole’The QAnon community reveals where the internet is headed.
‘On Tech With Shira Ovide’Facebook and its secret policies.

With U.S. Relief Measures Set to Phase Out, Some Face Economic RuinFederal and state programs intended to address job losses have mitigated some damage. Now the expiration of those programs represents a looming cliff.More than 40 million people — the equivalent of one out of every four American workers — have filed for unemployment benefits since mid-March.A French study found 1 in 10 diabetic patients with Covid-19 died within a week of being hospitalized. Here’s the latest.
The World Is Still Far From Herd Immunity for CoronavirusThe latest studies show that even in the hardest-hit cities, most people remain vulnerable.
Economy
Americans are scared about what will happen if pandemic relief isn’t renewed.
Trump signs order aimed at social networks as Twitter doubles down on labeling tweets.
American and Delta offer buyouts as airlines prepare for a long recovery.
Global
Even as countries move to reopen, the pandemic is growing at a faster pace.
As mass testing and contact tracing are rolled out in some nations, others offer lessons.
In France, a pre-dinner drink has become an act of ‘civil disobedience’ against government restrictions.
New York
City Council pushes to expand outdoor dining.
The New York State Legislature passed a rent relief bill.
N.J. governor says businesses vowing to defy rules are ‘playing with fire.’

Temperature Checks and Desk Shields: C.D.C. Suggests Big Changes to OfficesIf followed, the guidelines would transform the everyday experience of employees across the country, from executives to clerical workers.
10 Weeks Into New York Area’s Lockdown, Who Is Still Getting Sick?Nearly 50,000 people in the region have tested positive for the coronavirus in the last two weeks.
A Reporter’s Journey Across an Awakening and Oddly Changed EuropeEurope is gradually reopening after months of lockdown. We’re driving more than 3,700 miles to document life on a changed continent.

Updates: Governor Declares State of Emergency in MinneapolisGov. Tim Walz activated the Minnesota National Guard to help keep the peace after protests erupted in response to George Floyd’s death in police custody.

Trump’s Social Media Order May Harm One Person in Particular: TrumpWithout certain liability protections, companies like Twitter would have to be more aggressive about policing messages that press the boundaries — like the president’s.
How might the order change things? We explain.
Defying Trump, Twitter Doubles Down on Labeling TweetsTwitter continued fact-checking posts even as President Trump threatened to limit protections for social media companies.

China’s leader, Xi Jinping, center, at the closing session of the National People’s Congress in Beijing on Thursday. A plan to draft a national security law for Hong Kong was among the measures approved. Roman Pilipey/EPA, via Shutterstock

A G.O.P. Lawmaker Had the Virus. Nobody Told Democrats Exposed to Him.Democrats in Pennsylvania said Republicans were trying to avoid political embarrassment. “How dare you put our lives at risk?” said one angry Democrat.
Does a Crisis Spur Political Unity? Not This PandemicThe crisis has become one more partisan fight in a toxic political environment, our On Washington columnist writes.

As Hot Spots Shift, Pandemic Enters New PhaseFalling numbers in some of the hardest-hit places in the United States have offered signs of hope.But infections and deaths are rising in more than a half-dozen states, including Wisconsin and North Carolina.The pace is quickening worldwide, too, with outbreaks accelerating sharply in Argentina, Brazil, Colombia, Mexico and Peru. Here’s the latest.

Millions Relying on Pandemic Aid Can See Its End, and They’re ScaredEmergency programs have cushioned the shutdown’s impact on workers and businesses and lifted the economy, but may not outlast the coronavirus crisis.
